Tel.: +81 53 478 1172. Graphical abstract Dehydrogenation of propane with steam was investigated using novel LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) perovskite-type oxide (ABO3) catalysts. Optimization of the Co substitution ratio (x =0.2) enabled high propylene yield and selectivity. The perovskite structure of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 remained stable during dehydrogenation, as confirmed by XRD measurements. Dehydrogenation of propane over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 perovskite catalyst proceeded via reduction–oxidation (redox) of the perovskite oxide; oxidative dehydrogenation of propane consumed lattice oxygen in the perovskite and the consumed lattice oxygen was regenerated by H2O. Surface analyses conducted using XPS and XANES showed that a part of Mn4+ and Co3+ in LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 was reduced to Mn3+ and Co2+ during the reaction. The LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher selectivity at the same propane conversion compared with the selectivity to propylene over an industrial CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Keywords Propylene Dehydrogenation Perovskite Redox Lattice oxygen 1 Introduction Propylene is an important monomer, used in petrochemistry as a chemical intermediate for production of polypropylene, propylene oxide, and acrylonitrile [1,2]. Currently, main routes for the production of propylene are thermal cracking of naphtha and fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) [3–5]. Naphtha steam cracker and FCC units respectively produce ethylene and gasoline as main products. Propylene is a byproduct in these processes. The growth rate of propylene demand is estimated as 4–5% per year [2,6]. Therefore the operations of steam cracker and FCC units are optimized for less production of ethylene and gasoline, and for more production of propylene to meet increasing demand of propylene. However, the market demand of propylene will not be satisfied easily by these processes. A shortage risk of propylene supply is expected in the near future. Recently, a great deal of attention has been devoted to on-purpose technologies for propylene production, such as dehydrogenation of propane (DHP), olefin metathesis, and catalytic cracking of C4/C5 [2,7,8]. Among these processes, DHP is attractive in terms of the direct conversion of economic feedstock, i.e. propane to valuable propylene, which can contribute to the future chemical industry. (1) C3H8 →C3H6 +H2 A CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows high activity and selectivity to propylene on DHP. However, carbon deposition on the catalyst causes rapid deactivation during the reaction, which is an important shortcoming of DHP [9–13]. Normally, steam can suppress carbon deposition, but CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst itself is oxidized and deactivated by steam. Therefore, a regeneration process for coke combustion by diluted air is required after short reaction periods [14]. The cyclic regeneration process causes irreversible deactivation of the catalyst by phase transformation and sintering during calcination for coke removal. For the reasons presented above, development of a novel catalyst for stable production of propylene must be done. In terms of continuously production of propylene, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane to propylene (Eq. (2)) over V-based catalysts has been investigated widely [15–18]. (2) C3H8 +1/2O2 →C3H6 +H2O The nucleophilic oxygen species is present on V-based catalysts, which could be an excellent selective dehydrogenation catalyst in the presence of oxygen. The reaction mechanism over V-based catalysts is Mars van Krevelen redox pathways with lattice oxygen involved in the rate-determining CH bond activation steps [19–22]. According to Chen, a weak associative adsorption of propane on lattice oxygen proceeded and C3H8O* (O*: lattice oxygen) as the intermediate species was formed, subsequently CH cleavage via H-abstraction from propane using a neighboring lattice oxygen proceeded on the catalyst, and C3H7O* was produced [23]. Then, hydride elimination from the adsorbed alkoxide species occurred and followed by desorption of produced propylene. The remained two OH groups were combined to form H2O and lattice vacancy, accompanying with two-electron reduction of high-valent V n+ cations to form one V(n−2)+ or two V(n−1)+ cations. The replenishment of the consumed lattice oxygen proceeded via dissociative chemisorption of O2 and the reduced V centers were oxidized simultaneously. In addition, they showed that the rate constants for re-oxidation of the reduced centers using O2 are greater than for their reduction by C–H bond activation steps. Several researchers showed that more reducible oxides could bring enhancement of alkane ODH rates [24–34]. However, for DHP with O2, significant loss of propylene selectivity was confirmed because of total oxidation of propane and propylene to form CO and CO2 [35]. From these viewpoints, perovskite-type oxides are examined specifically as a dehydrogenation catalyst. Perovskite-type oxide is known to have high activity and high selectivity for dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene in the presence of steam by a redox mechanism [36,37]. Additionally, perovskite-type oxide suppressed production of surface carbon deposition through oxidation by the lattice oxygen in itself [38–41]. There have been some reports for investigating perovskite-type oxide as a dehydrogenation catalyst and membrane. According to Cimino et al., Pt/LaMnO3 catalyst showed high performance for ODH of ethane, which achieves a total molar yield to ethylene and acetylene in excess of 66% per pass, in correspondence to a C-atom selectivity to ethylene and ethane conversion both above 80% at very short contact time, i.e., significantly better than the best results reported in literature. The deposition of Pt onto LaMnO3 phase results in a better dispersion of the noble metal and can be effectively stabilized. Moreover, the catalyst performance is greatly enhanced thanks to the strong interaction between Pt and LaMnO3 [42,43]. The coexistence of alkanes and O2 leads to undesired combustion reactions due to the unselective role of weakly adsorbed O species. Yang et al. reported much higher ethylene selectivity of 80% at 84% conversion by using a mixed oxide ion conductor (Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2Ox) as a catalyst and a membrane than in a co-feed reactor system [44,45]. Rebeilleau-Dassonneville et al. also reported that the modification of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2Ox membrane by V/MgO micron grain or Pd nano cluster was found to enhance the catalytic performance [46]. In both cases, perovskite was used as the membrane of O2−ionic conductor. Therefore, perovskite-type oxides are applied to DHP with steam, expecting no coke formation during continuous production of propylene. For this study, La-based perovskite catalysts were applied to DHP with steam. Effects of A-site/B-site substitution on dehydrogenation activity were investigated. We also examined the reaction mechanism of highly active perovskite catalyst and clarified the effect of the co-feeding steam. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation La-based perovskite-type oxides as dehydrogenation catalysts were prepared using a complex polymerized method as follows: metal precursors were dissolved in distilled water. Then citric acid and ethylene glycol were added to the solution. The obtained solution was dried to be a gel and pre-calcined at 673K, then calcined at 1123K for 10h. A reference CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared using a conventional impregnation method with Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (Kanto Kagaku Co., Ltd., Japan) and γ-Al2O3 supplied from Catalysis Society of Japan (JRC-ALO-8), and sequential calcination at 923K in air. The loading amount of Cr was 15wt%, which was optimized in terms of catalytic activity. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The crystalline structure of calcined catalyst was determined using X-ray powder diffraction with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54Å, Rint-2000; Rigaku Corp.). The specific surface area of perovskite oxide was measured using N2 adsorption at 77K. The sample was outgassed at 573K for 2h before N2 adsorption. 2.3 Activity tests Catalytic activity, selectivity to product, and stability on DHP were examined in a conventional fixed bed reactor. The reaction temperature was 923K at atmospheric pressure in the presence of steam. The molar ratio of steam to propane was 0.5. The propane feed rate was 5mlmin−1 (SATP); the catalyst weight was 0.5g. The N2 carrier gas passed through a bubbler and entered into a furnace. The steam is supplied by bubbling with N2 through deionized water. The gaseous reactants and products such as C3H8, CO, CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and C3H6 after trapping of steam in the effluent gas through the cold trap were collected by microsyringe, subsequently injection to the off-line flame ionization detection gas chromatography (GC-8A; Shimadzu Co., Ltd., Japan). Other products except for the above products were not confirmed in the effluent gas. In addition, carbon balance was almost 100%. Table 1 shows the amount of carbon deposition after DHP with or without steam. In the case of DHP without steam, a small amount of carbon deposition was observed over perovskite catalyst. On the other hand, the carbon deposition after DHP with steam was not confirmed at all. The deposited carbon was supposed to be eliminated oxidatively by lattice oxygen in perovskite-type oxides in the presence of steam. Therefore, we did not take the depositied carbon into account for calculating selectivity, and selectivities were calculated based on gaseous products. Propane conversion and selectivity to products were calculated by using the following equations of (3) and (4). (3) Propane conv . = F CO + F CH 4 + F CO 2 + 2 × F C 2 H 4 + 2 × F C 2 H 6 + 3 × F C 3 H 6 3 × F C 3 H 8 × 100 (4) Selectivity to P = N × F P F CO + F CH 4 + F CO 2 + 2 × F C 2 H 4 + 2 × F C 2 H 6 + 3 × F C 3 H 6 × 100 In these equations, F denotes the flow rate of reactant and products. The terms of P and N indicated a certain product and the number of carbon in the product, respectively. 2.4 XPS and XANES measurement for characterization of catalyst surface X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCA1800; Ulvac-Phi Inc.) measurement was performed using non-monochromatic Al Kα radiation. The pass energy of the analyzer was at 23.5eV. Binding energies obtained for an identical sample were reproducible within ±0.1eV in general. Binding energy of C1s at 284.7eV was used for calibration. Co K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurement was conducted in a transmission mode with a Si (111) monochromator at BL14B2 of SPring-8 (Hyogo, Japan) operated at 8GeV. 2.5 Transient response experiment Transient response experiments were conducted to elucidate the reaction mechanism. The procedure was conducted as follows: first, propane and H2O were supplied to the catalyst bed. After stable activity was obtained, surface adsorbed species were purged and desorbed using a helium flow. Then, only H2O was supplied to the catalyst bed. Reaction conditions were the following: reaction temperature, 923K; catalyst weight, 0.15g; propane flow rate, 5mlmin−1; H2O, 5mlmin−1; internal standard gas, Ar, 3mlmin−1; and total flow rate, 300mlmin−1 as balanced with He. Temporal changes of reactants and products were observed using a quadruple mass spectrometer connected to the reactor outlet. Four parent peaks were scanned by the mass spectrometer: m/z; 2 (H2), 18 (H2O), 29 (propane) and 41 (propylene). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dehydrogenation of propane over LaBO3 (B=Cr, Mn, Fe, or Co) LaBO3 (B=Cr, Mn, Fe, or Co) perovskite-type oxide catalysts were investigated for their catalytic performance of DHP in the presence of steam at 923K. Fig. 1 presents the results of screening tests with time course over LaBO3 (B=Cr, Mn, Fe, or Co) catalyst. As show in Fig. 1, the LaCrO3, LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts show 13.1%, 11.2% and 12.5% conversions at 10min reaction under this condition (i.e. at lower conversion for kinetic evaluation), respectively, while, the LaCoO3 catalyst revealed a low propane conversion of 7.2%. Deactivation was observed over the LaCrO3 and LaCoO3 catalysts, on the other hand the deactivation did not almost proceed over the LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts. As shown in Table 1, the carbon deposition was not observed in the presence of steam. So, the deactivation of these two catalysts might be derived not from carbon laydown but from the decay of structure. Fig. 2(a) presents propylene yield with time course over LaBO3 (B=Cr, Mn, Fe, or Co) catalyst. Among these catalysts, LaCrO3 catalyst revealed the highest initial activity: 10.2%. However, deactivation proceeded over the catalyst. Propylene yield at 120min over LaCrO3 catalyst was 4.9%. LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts respectively showed 6.0 and 6.1% of propylene yield. Although initial activities of LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts were lower than that of LaCrO3 catalyst, these catalysts revealed higher stability. Propylene yield at 120min over LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts resulted respectively in 5.5 and 6.2%. However, LaCoO3 catalyst had little activity for DHP with steam. Fig. 2(b) presents selectivity to product over LaBO3 (B=Cr, Mn, Fe, or Co) catalyst at 10min reaction. The change of propylene selectivity with time on stream is shown in supporting data 1(a), and the drastic change of propylene selectivity was not observed over the active catalyst such as LaBO3 (B: Mn and Fe). Although the LaCrO3 catalyst showed the highest propylene selectivity, 78.1%, deactivation of the catalyst was observed as shown in Fig. 2(a). Under the steady state at 120min, propylene yields over LaCrO3, LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 showed similar values. However, the lowest propylene selectivity was obtained over LaCoO3 catalyst. In terms of dehydrogenation activity, selectivity to propylene and stability, LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts showed possibilities for effective catalysts. The mechanism of DHP in the presence of steam over perovskite-type oxides might be redox-type; propane was dehydrogenated via ODH using lattice oxygen (Eq. (5)) and the consumed lattice oxygen was replenished by steam (Eq. (6)). (5) C3H8 +O2− lat →C3H6 +H2O+2e− + V ox (6) H2O+2e− + V ox →H2 +O2− lat In that formula, V ox and O2− lat respectively represent the lattice vacancy and lattice oxygen. In the case of the LaCrO3 and LaCoO3 catalysts, the rate for regenerating lattice oxygen was slower than the releasing rate of lattice oxygen, while the regenerating rate of lattice oxygen was considered to be comparable to the releasing rate of lattice oxygen over the LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts. Therefore, in terms of catalytic activity and stability, the LaMnO3 and LaFeO3 catalysts were suitable for the dehydrogenation catalysts. Further investigation was conducted based on LaMnO3 catalyst, which showed higher propylene selectivity than LaFeO3 catalyst did. Reportedly, A-site substitution in perovskite-type oxide can enhance the catalytic activity [47–49]. From that perspective, A-site substitution in LaMnO3 catalyst was investigated for DHP with steam. 3.2 Effect of A-site or B-site substitution For investigation of the effect of partial substitution of La cation in A site with alkaline-earth metal cation in LaMnO3 catalyst on the activity for DHP, activity tests were conducted over La0.8A0.2MnO3 (A=Mg, Ca, Sr or Ba) catalyst. Fig. 3 shows propylene yield over these catalysts with time on stream. Among these catalysts, the substitution by Ca was effective; La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 catalyst revealed 8.9% propylene yield, whereas LaMnO3 catalyst revealed 6.0% propylene yield. Although the initial activity of La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 catalyst was about 1.5 times higher than that of LaMnO3 catalyst, the catalytic activity decreased. Other catalysts showed lower activity than LaMnO3 catalyst. For considering the effect of Ca-substitution, the formation rate of propylene per specific surface area, which was defined as the specific activity, is calculated and also shown in Fig. 3. LaMnO3 catalyst showed 4.7μmolm−2 min−1, whereas 3.8μmolm−2 min−1 on La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 catalyst. Similarly, other substituted catalysts showed lower specific activity than LaMnO3 catalyst. From these results, the substitution of A-site was ineffective for increasing the catalytic activity for the dehydrogenation of propane. The change of propylene selectivity with time course is shown in supporting data 1(b). The A-site substitution was not effective for enhancement of propylene selectivity, except for Ca-substitution. The selectivity of propylene was slightly improved by Ca-substitution at the initial stage of the reaction, but its selectivity decreased with time course. At 120min, LaMnO3 catalyst showed higher propylene selectivity over La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 catalyst. B-site substitution in perovskite structure is a well-known method for controlling the amount of mobile lattice oxygen in the perovskite [50,51]. We also found that substitution of B-site Mn cation with Fe promotes catalytic activity on dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene over La0.8Ba0.2MnO3 perovskite catalyst [36,37]. Therefore, for this work, 20% of the Mn cation in LaMnO3 catalyst was substituted with Cr, Fe, Co, or Ni, and the catalytic performance was investigated. Fig. 4(a) shows the propylene yield with time course over LaB0.2Mn0.8O3 (B=Cr, Fe, Co, or Ni) catalysts. Among these substituted catalysts, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 showed high dehydrogenation activity compared to LaMnO3 catalyst. The LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher specific activity than other substituted catalyst. The unusual trend over LaMn0.8Ni0.2O3 catalyst was observed. This phenomenon was considered to be derived from the reduction of the catalyst. In the initial stage of the reaction, the catalyst might be reduced and the lattice oxygen was consumed gradually under the reducing atmosphere. Then, the Ni metal was segregated from the structure. Presumably, from about 90min of the reaction, the dehydrogenation reaction might proceed on the Ni metal. The substitution of Mn with Cr promoted dehydrogenation reaction and the promoting effect was not confirmed by the Fe substitution. Compared the catalytic activity over the LaCr0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst with that over the LaCrO3 catalyst, the Cr-substituted catalyst showed higher formation rate of propylene. Such result indicated that a synergistic effect was also found, like LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. However, the LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed 1.8 times higher formation rate than the LaCr0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. Fig. 4(b) shows propylene selectivity with time course. As shown in Fig. 4(b), propylene selectivity was enhanced by the substitution of Co cation from 54.0% to 68.2%. So, the combination of Mn and Co is more effective for the enhancement of the dehydrogenation activity. Therefore, further optimization of Co substitution ratio on dehydrogenation activity and propylene selectivity was investigated. Fig. 5(a) shows the propylene yield at 10min and at 120min. In addition, Fig. 5(b) shows selectivity to products. From Fig. 5(a), LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher initial activity of 10.4%, which was higher than other substituted catalysts such as LaCo0.1Mn0.9O3 (6.6%), LaCo0.15Mn0.85O3 (10.0%), LaCo0.3Mn0.7O3 (9.9%), LaCo0.4Mn0.6O3 (9.1%), LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 (8.3%), and LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 (6.6%). For considering the deactivation of catalysts, we defined the deactivation degree as the following Eq. (7). (7) Durability [ − ] = Propylene yield at 120 min / % Propylene yield at 10 min / % Durability of these catalysts was as follows: LaCo0.1Mn0.9O3 (0.92), LaCo0.15Mn0.85O3 (0.89), LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 (0.84), LaCo0.3Mn0.7O3 (0.84), LaCo0.4Mn0.6O3 (0.86), LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 (0.73), and LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 (0.18). The Co substitution in LaMnO3 lowered the durability of catalyst at a high substitution ratio. Regarding selectivity to products, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and LaCo0.3Mn0.7O3 catalysts showed high propylene selectivity. The drastic change of propylene selectivity with time course was not observed over the candidate catalysts such as LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and LaCo0.3Mn0.7O3 catalysts as shown in supporting data 1(c). An increase of the Co substitution ratio to more than 0.3 brought a decrease of propylene selectivity. An optimal value of Co substitution ratio (x =0.2–0.3) is believed to exist, at which the highest propylene yield, selectivity, and stability are obtainable. 3.3 Effect of dehydrogenation atmosphere on the structure of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalyst Based on the results presented above, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst was found to be a good candidate for the dehydrogenation of propane in the presence of steam. A reducing atmosphere such as dehydrogenation of propane might cause a collapse of the crystal structure. Therefore, for considering structural stability under dehydrogenation conditions, the structure of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) was investigated. Fig. 6(a) and (b) show XRD patterns of as-made LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts and of these catalysts after 120min reaction, respectively. Fig. 6(a) shows that all as-made LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts exhibited a perovskite structure. The peak was shifted to a higher angle by an increment of the Co substitution ratio. The lattice constant decreased because the ionic radius of Co3+ was smaller than that of Mn3+. After 120min reaction, LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalyst was reduced to a La2CoO4 structure. The LaCoO3 catalyst was reduced to Co metal and La2O3. In contrast, the LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst retained its perovskite structure stably after DHP reaction. To elucidate the effects of atmosphere on the catalyst structure stability, additional experiments were conducted in an inert gas atmosphere or a reducing hydrogen atmosphere of hydrogen at 813K. The respective XRD patterns are shown in Figs. 6(c) and (d). From Fig. 6(c), all of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts were stable in the inert atmosphere, and the release of lattice oxygen in perovskite structure did not proceed even at zero oxygen partial pressure. In a reducing hydrogen atmosphere, the perovskite structure of LaCoO3, LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3, and LaMnO3 catalysts was collapsed by releasing lattice oxygen, which was reduced by hydrogen. Fig. 6(d) shows that catalysts of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 were not reduced. They maintained their stable structure even in a hydrogen atmosphere. The stable and high activity of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst was derived from the structural stability in the reducing atmosphere. 3.4 Surface analyses of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst by XPS and XAFS To clarify the working state of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0, 0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts under a reaction condition, XPS measurements were conducted. Before XPS measurements, the catalyst was exposed to the reaction atmosphere for 15min. The absolute binding energy of the Co2p peak was not helpful in identifying the cobalt chemical state because of the small shifts between Co2+ and Co3+. Therefore, we evaluated the binding energies of Mn2p core-levels of as-made and used LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0, 0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts in Table 2 . The XPS spectra of these catalysts are shown in supporting data 2 and 3. For the as-made LaMnO3 catalyst, the peak of Mn2p included two peaks at 642.63 and 641.62eV. Former and latter peaks were attributed respectively to Mn4+ and Mn3+ [52–54]. Concentrations of Mn4+ and Mn3+ were, respectively, 31.4% and 68.6%. The catalyst after dehydrogenation reaction contained two peaks at 642.63 and 641.43eV, which were, respectively, attributed to Mn4+ and Mn3+. Concentrations of Mn4+and Mn3+ were, respectively, 20.9% and 79.1%. The result implied that surface Mn cation on LaMnO3 catalyst was reduced by propane during the DHP reaction. As-made LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts contained Mn4+ and Mn3+, as shown in Table 2. The concentration of Mn4+ increased with increased Co substitution ratio in the as-made LaCo x Mn1−x O3 structure. The average oxidation state of Mn increased by increasing the replacement ratio of Co. Regarding used LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5 and 0.8) catalysts, Mn4+ and Mn3+ presented on the surface of catalysts. Especially, high concentrations of Mn3+ were observed over LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalyst. LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 catalysts were not so reduced compared with as-made catalysts because of the structural stability described in the previous section. To investigate the oxidation number of Co on LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts, the oxidation number of Co was determined using Co K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra. Fig. 7(a) shows Co K-edge XANES spectra of as-made catalysts, CoO and Fig. 7(b) shows that of used catalysts. In the XANES spectra, the XANES spectra of some Co standard compounds (CoO, Co foil and LaCoO3 prepared by a complex polymerized method) were obtained. The reference sample of Co3O4 shows two characteristics peaks at 7718 and 7727eV, which assigned to ±2 oxidation state (tetrahedral coordination) and ±3 oxidation state (octahedral coordination) in the structure, respectively [55]. While, the LaCoO3 exhibited a sharp absorption peak at 7723eV. This peak is similar to XANES spectra obtained previously by other groups [56,57]. This peak is derived from the dipole-allowed 1s→4p transitions at the Co K-edge [58]. As for LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts, two peaks were observed at about 7722–7723 and 7727eV. With decreasing oxidation state of Co, the main white line peak (7723eV) is expected to decrease in energy position. The substitution of Mn in B-site of LaCoO3 might reduce the oxidation state of Co cation. Incorporation of Mn4+ in the structure produced Co2+ cation, which was supported by XPS measurement as shown in Table 2. In addition, the shoulder peak of 7727eV was observed over the Mn-substituted catalyst, despite the shoulder peak was not observed over the LaCoO3 sample. Presumably, the similar site of octahedral coordination of Co3O4 might be formed since the structure is distorted by the substitution of Mn cation. Among LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts, particularly LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalyst showed high ratio of octahedral coordination site in Co3O4 (7727eV) to the site in LaCoO3 (7722–7723eV). According to Table 2, higher ratio of Mn4+ was existed on the LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalyst, compared with LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 and LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. It resulted in high ratio of the octahedral coordination site. Compared with XANES spectra of LaCoO3, the adsorption edge of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts shifted to lower energy of the edge position. The edge in the XANES spectrum shifts when the valence state of cobalt is altered. In the lower valence state, electrons are bound weakly to the Co nucleus. Therefore, the absorption edge at which the X-ray starts to knock out electrons is expected to be shifted to a lower energy. The oxidation numbers of Co on LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts were smaller than the trivalent ion. The average oxidation number was estimated using the method reported by some researchers [59,60]. First, a calibration curve was produced based on absorption edge shift (ΔE 0) and the valence of reference sample, which was Co foil, CoO, Co3O4, and LaCoO3. Here, ΔE 0 signifies the difference of energy between E 0 of Co foil (7709.5eV) and E 0 of each sample, which was at half height of the normalized absorption at the Co K-edge. The relation between ΔE 0 of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5 and 0.8) catalyst and the calculated average oxidation number of Co is shown in Fig. 7(c). A linear trend can be ascertained, as the figure shows. Table 3 shows the oxidation number of Co and surface composition of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0.2, 0.5, and 0.8) catalysts. Regarding the LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst, average oxidation numbers of Co for as-made and used were, respectively, 2.42 and 2.34, which implied that the catalyst is slightly reduced during dehydrogenation. Similarly, the average oxidation quantities of Co for as-made and used LaCo0.5Mn0.5O3 catalysts were, respectively, 2.52 and 2.44. The average oxidation numbers of Co for as-made and used LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalysts were 2.69 and 2.02, respectively. LaCo0.8Mn0.2O3 catalyst was reduced to Co2+ under dehydrogenation conditions. Results show that the Co maintained the state of mixture of divalent and trivalent ion during dehydrogenation reaction at low substitution ratio with no collapse of perovskite structure. However, the Co incorporated in the perovskite structure was reduced to appear as Co2+ at a high substitution ratio. 3.5 Reaction pathway over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst Catalytic nature and reaction pathway were investigated by changing propane conversion in a lower propane conversion range (<15%) under various W/Fs from 4.1 to 41ghmol−1. Thermal cracking (C3H8 →CH4 +C2H4) proceeds at the reaction temperature. For elucidating the only contribution of the catalyst, we subtracted the products flow rate of thermal reaction from that of the catalytic reaction. Fig. 8 shows the selectivity to products at the initial stage of the reaction as a function of propane conversion over the LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. The propylene selectivity increased as approaching zero propane conversion. Selectivities to propylene and CO2 were almost 80% and 20%, respectively, at the initial step of the reaction. The result indicated that dehydrogenation reaction and propane oxidation by lattice oxygen as primary reactions proceeded over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. Then, methane, ethylene and CO were observed with increasing propane conversion. Perovskite-type oxides were used for cracking of hydrocarbon, however it was used as not a catalyst, but a support, except for Ni-based oxide [61]. The cracking reaction over perovskite alone might not so important in this case. Therefore, the hydrogenolysis of propylene was regarded as proceeding over the catalyst according to the following Eq. (8). (8) C3H6 +H2 →CH4 +C2H4 The detected CO was regarded as derived from steam reforming of ethylene and propylene. From these results, we calculated each reaction rate of LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (x =0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.8, or 1) catalysts on a carbon molar basis. Table 4 shows reaction rates per unit surface area: dehydrogenation rate (R DH), the rate of propane oxidation by lattice oxygen (R OX), the hydrogenolysis rate (R HG), and the reform rate (R ref). From Table 4, R DH was found to be promoted with increasing Co substitution ratio. Additionally, R DH, R HG and R OX were enhanced by increasing the Co substitution ratio. Table 4 also shows the ratio of R DH/R HG, and R DH/R OX. The catalyst of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 revealed the highest R DH/R HG (4.8) and R DH/R OX (12.7) ratios among these catalysts because of the suppression of further consecutive reaction of propylene. We conducted a comparison of catalytic properties of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the presence of steam by changing the propane conversion in a higher propane conversion range (>10%) under various W/Fs. Fig. 9 shows the results of selectivity to propylene at the initial stage of the reaction as a function of propane conversion over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 and CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Over both catalysts, propylene selectivity decreased with an increment of propane conversion. Successive reactions proceeded over the catalysts, which caused a decrease of propylene selectivity. Selectivity to propylene over CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst decreased significantly with an increment of propane conversion. However, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher selectivity to propylene than CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst did, even at higher conversion. For comparing the activity over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst and that over CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the surface area of CrO x on γ-Al2O3 was calculated. The surface area of supported CrO x was estimated by the extension of the Defosse model proposed by Kerkhof and Moulijn [62]. The crystal size of CrO x was estimated from the relative XPS intensity of the sample. Firstly, the theoretical intensity ratio of I 0 p/I 0 s was calculated. Here, “p” denotes atomically dispersed loaded phase, i.e., Cr and “s” represents the support, i.e., γ-Al2O3. The experimental intensity ratio of I p/I s is given by the following expression (9): (9) I p I s = I 0 p [ 1 − exp ( − d / λ p ) ] / d / λ p I 0 s where “d” is the length of the edge of the cubic crystallites of the loaded phase, and “λ p” is the mean escape depth of the photoelectrons in the loaded phase. The photoelectron cross sections and mean escape depths of the photoelectrons used in these calculations were taken from Scofield and Penn, respectively [63,64]. Particle size “d” of the Cr was determined by solving Eq. (9). The surface area of the loaded Cr on the γ-Al2O3 was estimated from the particle size of Cr. As a result of the calculation of length of the cubic crystallites over the catalyst, the mean particle size was resulted in 1.35nm. This value was close to that in a literature [65]. The surface area of the loaded CrO x was estimated to 116m2 g-cat−1 by the calculation from the particle size. As a result of the activity test over the CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the catalyst showed 42.4% of propylene yield at 10min reaction. And the deactivation proceeded on the catalyst; 9.5% propylene yield was obtained at 120min reaction. We calculated the formation rate of propylene based on the initial value. Consequently, the formation rate of propylene per specific surface area of CrO x was resulted in 1.5μmolm−2 min−1 over the CrO x /Al2O3 catalyst. Compared with the formation rate over perovskite-type oides, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed 7.6 times higher propylene formation rate per specific surface area of the catalyst. Therefore, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 can be regarded as a promising catalyst for dehydrogenation of propane in the presence of steam. 3.6 Role of co-feeding steam in terms of reaction mechanism We sought to clarify the role of the co-feeding steam on the catalytic property and reaction mechanism over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. Fig. 10(a) and (b) respectively show effects of steam partial pressure on the propylene yield and selectivity. From Fig. 10(a), the initial propylene yield without co-feeding steam can be inferred as 8.2%. The initial activity was increased to 10.4% by a co-feeding steam (3.5kPa), and stability was also improved. The amounts of carbon deposition on LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst after 3h DHP reaction with or without steam were, respectively, 3.6mgg-cat−1 and 0mgg-cat−1 as shown in Table 1. Carbon deposition over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst was suppressed by co-feeding steam of 3.5kPa. Further increasing of partial pressure of steam over 7.0kPa suppressed the DHP reaction. For clarifying the role of steam, the reaction mechanism on LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst was examined using transient response experiments. First, DHP in the presence of steam was conducted over the catalyst. After stable activity was obtained, adsorbed species on the catalyst surface was cleaned off by purging with helium. Next, steam alone was introduced to the catalyst bed and the temporal change of products was measured. Stable values reached at 30min of the reaction. Fig. 11 portrays results for transient experiments over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst. Reaction time “0” signifies that the feed was changed to steam alone. After switching the reaction gas to helium at–10min, steam decreased probably because H2O on the surface of the catalyst was desorbed by purging with helium. Subsequently, H2O was supplied to the catalyst bed at 0min, H2 was produced by feeding H2O, and other gases such as CO and CO2 were not observed. Therefore, we inferred that the vacancy of lattice oxygen in LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst produced during the stable reaction of DHP was regenerated using H2O according to Eq. (5). Here, the regeneration rate was defined as the hydrogen flow rate at the starting time of steam supply, and the regeneration rate was 12.3μmolmin−1. It is particularly interesting that the regeneration rate was almost equal to the hydrogen flow rate under the steady state reaction: 12.1μmolmin−1. Results indicate that the produced hydrogen under a steady state reaction was derived from hydrogen generated with regeneration of lattice oxygen: Eq. (6). Fig. 12 shows the amount of the lattice oxygen released from the as-made and the spent LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalysts during temperature programmed reduction (TPR) measurements in the presence of H2. Here, the spent catalyst means the catalyst after 120min reaction of DHP with steam. The amount of the lattice oxygen released in the as-made catalyst was determined by the weight loss of 6.3wt% obtained from the result of TPR measurements, which was caused by reduction of perovskite-type oxide. And its value corresponded to 0.95molmol-cat−1 of the amount of the lattice oxygen released. As for the spent catalyst, the amount of the lattice oxygen released was resulted in 0.63molmol-cat−1. The differnce of the amount of the lattice oxygen released between the as-made and the spent was 0.32molmol-cat−1 (=0.95–0.63). This result indicated that the lattice oxygen was consumed under DHP reaction consitions. Theoretical calculation for the amount of the lattice oxygen on (111) faces of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst is 0.015molmol-cat−1. So, the amount of 0.32molmol-cat−1 of the lattice oxygen corresponds to about 21 layers of lattice oxygen in the catalyst. The result indicates that the surface and subsuface lattice oxygen are reduced by propane and the vicinity of catalyst surface is considerably reduced state. In the preliminary study for dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene over the perovskite-type oxide catalyst, we investigated the dependence of release and regeneration rates of lattice oxygen on its capacity in the catalyst [66]. We proposed that the rate for bulk diffusion of lattice oxygen from the subsurface to the surface of the catalyst decreased concomitantly with decreasing the capacity of lattice oxygen of the catalyst. The threshold of the contribution of the bulk diffusion was about 2–3 layers of lattice oxygen in the catalyst. As being reduced further, the release rate for lattice oxygen from the bulk to the surface of the catalyst was sufficiently low: ethylbenzene did not react to bulk lattice oxygen in the catalyst, but reacted to the regenerated lattice oxygen by H2O. In the case of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst for DHP with steam, the catalyst was more reduced. Therefore, the lattice oxygen at the suface, which was regenerated by steam, probably contributed to the consumption of lattice oxygen. Consequently, the redox-type mechanism reaction, which uses lattice oxygen and its vacancy, proceeded on the LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst in the steady state dehydrogenation reaction. These results show that steam is extremely effective to regenerate the lattice oxygen of the catalyst and suppress the carbon deposition on the catalyst, but excess steam inhibited the reaction because of adsorption on the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this work, we investigated DHP with steam using perovskite-type oxide catalysts, expecting high activity and selectivity. LaCo x Mn1–x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) catalysts were active and selective for DHP. Among these catalysts, LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst revealed high activity, selectivity, and stability, and it showed high stability even in a reducing atmosphere confirmed by XRD and XANES study. The obtained LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher propylene selectivity than an industrial catalyst of CrO x /γ-Al2O3 at the same propane conversion. The effect of steam was not only elimination of coke deposition on the catalyst, but also regeneration of lattice oxygen, which was consumed by oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. coredata.dc:description: Dehydrogenation of propane with steam was investigated using novel LaCo x Mn1−x O3 (0≤ x ≤1) perovskite-type oxide (ABO3) catalysts. Optimization of the Co substitution ratio (x =0.2) enabled high propylene yield and selectivity. The perovskite structure of LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 remained stable during dehydrogenation, as confirmed by XRD measurements. Dehydrogenation of propane over LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 perovskite catalyst proceeded via reduction–oxidation (redox) of the perovskite oxide; oxidative dehydrogenation of propane consumed lattice oxygen in the perovskite and the consumed lattice oxygen was regenerated by H2O. Surface analyses conducted using XPS and XANES showed that a part of Mn4+ and Co3+ in LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 was reduced to Mn3+ and Co2+ during the reaction. The LaCo0.2Mn0.8O3 catalyst showed higher selectivity at the same propane conversion compared with the selectivity to propylene over an industrial CrO x /γ-Al2O3 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Stable and selective perovskite catalyst for dehydrogenation of propane working with redox mechanism
